Description: Mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; finely modelled scarab, with high back, much broader, rounder shape than usual; back with clearly delineated clypeus, prothorax indicated by double incised line, while elytra divided by triple line (double suture); feathering shown clearly on forelegs; at side, legs well-modelled with deeply undercut triangle; underside deeply incised with representation of two animals, arranged one above the other: herbivore lying on its back while lion gnaws at its belly; scene framed by square pellet border; pierced longitudinally; in hard paste, greyish blue in colour with a glossy finish.
Curator's comments: Lion attacking a prey is a recurrent theme on Egyptian blue scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Eastern Greece, and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 121-127, type XXXIV, subtype B1-17, see especially B16 for this piece). This group varies in style with other animal representations on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids - animals with more elongated bodies, finer incisions - giving the impression that they are of better workmanship (Gorton 1996, 122). This type of representation can be paralleled to Archaic Greek gems, with single oval line incised round edge (e.g. Walters 1926, pl. VIII, no. 450; see also Hölbl 1979, pl. 77, no. 263 for similar frame and opposed animals). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Hölbl, G. 1979, Beziehungen der ägyptischen Kultur zu Altitalien (EPRO 62), Leiden. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Walters, H.E. 1926, Catalogue of the engraved gems and cameos Greek, Etruscan and Roman in the British Museum, London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 138)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 123, Type XXXIV B16)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.09) (phase 3)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2016, 19 May-27 Nov, BM exhibition Sunken Treasures
